results.abstract: Capsule reviews of new books for children
results.snippet: GRANDPA TAKES ME TO THE MOON. By Timothy R. Gaffney. Illustrated by Barry Root. Tambourine. $16. (Ages 4 and up) At bedtime, Grandpa tells about the time he went to the moon on an Apollo spacecraft. The illustrations show the mission, but with...
results.lead_paragraph: GRANDPA TAKES ME TO THE MOON. By Timothy R. Gaffney. Illustrated by Barry Root. Tambourine. $16. (Ages 4 and up) At bedtime, Grandpa tells about the time he went to the moon on an Apollo spacecraft. The illustrations show the mission, but with wrinkled grandfather, youthful grandson and another astronaut as the crew. It's a surprisingly affecting book, recalling the thrill of those journeys. THE CLASSROOM AT THE END OF THE HALL. By Douglas Evans. Illustrated by Larry Di Fiori. Front Street. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12) The custodian at the W. T. Melon Elementary School tells some tall tales about ghosts and mischief in the building. You can believe them, or laugh, or both. SHILOH SEASON. By Phyllis Reynolds Naylor. Atheneum. $15. (Ages 8 to 12) The 1992 Newbery Medal went to the author's novel about how Marty Preston got to keep the dog called Shiloh. Hunting season is coming and Judd Travers, Shiloh's cruel and unhappy former owner, is causing trouble again. CAT IS SLEEPY. Written and illustrated by Satoshi Kitamura. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $4.95. (Ages 2 and up) The marmalade cat searches the household of a musical boy and a literary girl, and finally finds a place to nap. One of a series of finely thought-out, beautifully illustrated concept board books for toddlers and their families. AN AMERICAN HERO: The True Story of Charles A. Lindbergh. By Barry Denenberg. Scholastic. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up) This sophisticated and thoughtful account of the life of the aviation pioneer includes the kidnapping of his son and also discusses his personal political journey. WALLPAPER FROM SPACE. By Daniel Pinkwater. Illustrated by Jill Pinkwater. Atheneum. $15. (Ages 6 to 9) The story starts with Steve's mother redecorating and finding spaceship wallpaper for his bedroom. It turns out to be fantastic paper and leads to a great adventure.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis is launched from Cape Canaveral with crew of six astronauts on 10-day mission; will carry supplies for orbiting Russian Mir space station; Dr Jerry L Linenger, American physician, will replace astronaut John E Blaha aboard Mir for four-and-a-half month stay; photo (M)

headline.main: Atlantis Blasts Off in Swift Pursuit of Mir Space Station

results.snippet: In a celestial chase around the Earth, the space shuttle Atlantis dashed across the skies today, pursuing the Russian Mir space station for a rendezvous and linkup.    Atlantis, with a crew of six, blasted into chilly, pre-dawn skies today on flaming...
results.lead_paragraph: In a celestial chase around the Earth, the space shuttle Atlantis dashed across the skies today, pursuing the Russian Mir space station for a rendezvous and linkup. Atlantis, with a crew of six, blasted into chilly, pre-dawn skies today on flaming rockets that remained visible from the launching site for almost eight minutes. Looking like a bright star, the shuttle finally disappeared into the darkness after it was more than 300 miles away from the Kennedy Space Center and about 70 miles high.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis docks with Russian Mir space station after three-day chase across sky; astronauts on both sides greet each other after docking; John E Blaha, US astronaut who has been living on Russian station since Sept, will swap places with Dr Jerry L Linenger, physician scheduled for four-and-a-half month stay on Mir (M)

headline.main: After 3-Day Pursuit, Shuttle Docks With Russian Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis caught and docked with the Russian Mir space station tonight after a three-day chase across the sky.    The shuttle commander, Capt. Michael A. Baker of the Navy, used flight controls at the rear deck of Atlantis to slowly...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis caught and docked with the Russian Mir space station tonight after a three-day chase across the sky. The shuttle commander, Capt. Michael A. Baker of the Navy, used flight controls at the rear deck of Atlantis to slowly position the shuttle for the linkup, as other astronauts, including Cmdr. Brent Jett of the Navy and Dr. John M. Grunsfeld, assisted by monitoring cameras and laser range-finders.

results.abstract: Shuttle Atlantis and Russian space station Mir begin five days of joint operations as American astronaut John E Blaha gets ready to return home after four months on Russian craft; Atlantis and Mir are linked after nearly flawless rendezvous and docking; Blaha is being replaced on Mir by Dr Jerry L Linenger, a physician scheduled for stay of four and a half months; photo (M)

headline.main: After Joyful Space Docking, 2-Nation Crew Gets to Work

results.snippet: The shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir began five days of joint operations today as the American astronaut John E. Blaha got ready to return home after four months on the Russian craft.    Atlantis and Mir are linked, forming a...
results.lead_paragraph: The shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir began five days of joint operations today as the American astronaut John E. Blaha got ready to return home after four months on the Russian craft. Atlantis and Mir are linked, forming a 265-ton space complex, after a nearly flawless rendezvous and docking on Tuesday night. Atlantis locked onto Mir's docking module at 10:54 P.M., Eastern standard time, 240 miles above central Russia.

results.abstract: American astronaut John E Blaha, after four-month stay aboard Russia's Mir space station, says it has come to resemble cluttered glove box of old car (S)

headline.main: Another Vanishing Act on Cluttered Mir

results.snippet: In space, one cannot just roll down the window and toss things out. That is why Russia's 11-year-old Mir space station has come to resemble the cluttered glove box of an old car.    After a four-month stay aboard the Mir, the American astronaut John...
results.lead_paragraph: In space, one cannot just roll down the window and toss things out. That is why Russia's 11-year-old Mir space station has come to resemble the cluttered glove box of an old car. After a four-month stay aboard the Mir, the American astronaut John E. Blaha could not find a small, broken fan that he had removed from a refrigerator. Mr. Blaha listed the fan as lost in space when he moved his belongings into the docked space shuttle Atlantis today.

results.abstract: Astronaut John E Blaha take one last treadmill run in orbit, testing vibration-free exercise device; space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled to bring Blaha home from Russian space station Mir on Jan 22 after 128 days in space (M)
results.snippet: His four-month space odyssey almost over, the astronaut John E. Blaha took one last treadmill run in orbit today. The successful test of the vibration-free exercise device headed off an extension of the shuttle's mission.     The space shuttle...
results.lead_paragraph: His four-month space odyssey almost over, the astronaut John E. Blaha took one last treadmill run in orbit today. The successful test of the vibration-free exercise device headed off an extension of the shuttle's mission. The space shuttle Atlantis is scheduled to bring Mr. Blaha home from the Russian space station Mir on Wednesday morning after 128 days in space for the American.

results.abstract: John E Blaha, astronaut who spent four months on Russian space station Mir, says he got depressed after few weeks there and that his stay would have been easier if he had fellow American on board; expresses his feelings from space shuttle Atlantis, which is scheduled to bring him home on Jan 22 (M)

headline.main: Astronaut Tells Of Down Side To Space Life

results.snippet: John E. Blaha, the astronaut who spent four months on the Russian space station Mir, said today that he got depressed after a few weeks there and that his stay would have been easier if he had had private quarters and a fellow American on board.   ...
results.lead_paragraph: John E. Blaha, the astronaut who spent four months on the Russian space station Mir, said today that he got depressed after a few weeks there and that his stay would have been easier if he had had private quarters and a fellow American on board. ''Isolation is a tough thing,'' Mr. Blaha said from the space shuttle Atlantis, which is scheduled to bring him home on Wednesday just after sunrise.

results.abstract: American astronaut John Blaha returns to Earth after four months aboard Russian space station Mir; agrees to be carried off space shuttle Atlantis so that doctors can study effects of weightlessness (S)

headline.main: Shuttle Lands With a Long-Term Traveler

results.snippet: After a punishing four months aboard the Russian space station Mir, John Blaha returned to Earth today and instead of playing the hero, he allowed himself to be carried off the shuttle Atlantis on a stretcher.    It was the first time an astronaut...
results.lead_paragraph: After a punishing four months aboard the Russian space station Mir, John Blaha returned to Earth today and instead of playing the hero, he allowed himself to be carried off the shuttle Atlantis on a stretcher. It was the first time an astronaut has agreed to be carried off after a long flight. The decision delighted doctors for the space agency, who want to gauge the effects of long-term weightlessness on the body, including dizziness and weakened bones and muscles.

results.abstract: Problems with Russia's space program have delayed module that is centerpiece of proposed international space station, endangering entire project; National Aeronautics and Space Administration has decided to build stopgap module to enable station plans to go forward; races to contain political damage; House Science Committee chairman Rep F James Sensenbrenner Jr says plan is in danger of unraveling, interview; plan calls for outpost to be built in stages by 15 nations, replacing cold war hostilities with global teamwork; photos (M)

headline.main: RUSSIA IS FUMBLING ITS CONTRIBUTION TO SPACE STATION

results.snippet: Problems with Russia's space program have delayed its main contribution to the proposed international space station, endangering the entire project, some experts say.    The Russian module is a centerpiece of the orbiting outpost, which  involves 15...
results.lead_paragraph: Problems with Russia's space program have delayed its main contribution to the proposed international space station, endangering the entire project, some experts say. The Russian module is a centerpiece of the orbiting outpost, which involves 15 nations and is expected to cost at least $50 billion and be the size of a football field. The station is meant to symbolize, and help foster, a new era of East-West accord and is an important part of the Clinton Administration's Russia policy. It is also NASA's biggest and most politically complex project.

results.abstract: Jell-O museum is open in June in LeRoy, NY, where product was created 100 years ago by Pearl B Wait, cough syrup manufacturer, and named by his wife, May; in 1996, about 1.1 million boxes of the gelatin dessert were sold or eaten daily in US; photo (S)
results.snippet: IT'S Jell-O's centennial.    A Jell-O museum is to open in June in LeRoy, N.Y., where the product was created 100 years ago by Pearl B. Wait, a cough syrup manufacturer, and named by his wife, May.
results.lead_paragraph: IT'S Jell-O's centennial. A Jell-O museum is to open in June in LeRoy, N.Y., where the product was created 100 years ago by Pearl B. Wait, a cough syrup manufacturer, and named by his wife, May.
